Expectation1: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation1: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with severe, life-threatening symptoms of an unknown illness.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: The hospital was unusually busy this Sunday morning, and I was already running on little sleep. As a doctor, I knew my duty: every patient deserved my full attention, especially the man who had just been rushed in, gasping for breath, his skin pale and clammy. His symptoms were baffling, and I needed to focus, to sift through every possible diagnosis, order the right tests, and act quickly. But as I glanced at the clock, I realized the church bells would soon ring. My congregation would gather, voices rising in worship, and I felt the familiar tug of my Christian faith. I had promised myself I’d make it to service this week, to reconnect with my community and God. Yet here I was, torn between the sacred call to worship and the urgent need to heal. My heart ached with guilt and longing, caught between the expectations of my profession and my faith, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
